label: Category Assortment Optimization
description: SKU rationalization with sales velocity and profitability analysis achieving 15-25% SKU reduction while maintaining 98%+ revenue through elimination of low-performing items.

traditional.workflow: 1. Category manager reviews 250 SKU cereal assortment annually: 'Too many SKUs, need to simplify'. 2. Exports sales report from last 12 months, sorts by revenue, identifies bottom 50 SKUs representing 5% of sales. 3. Manually reviews each SKU: 'This one only sells 10 units/month, maybe discontinue?'. 4. Creates discontinuation list based primarily on sales volume, submits for approval. 5. Post-implementation discovers issues: discontinued SKU#123 was only gluten-free option (customer complaints), SKU#456 had 40% margin (lost high-profit item), SKU#789 was required for promotional bundle. 6. Assortment decisions lack holistic analysis (profitability, customer preference, strategic value).
constraints: Annual assortment review (too infrequent for dynamic markets)
Sales volume only criterion (ignores profitability, strategic value)
Manual SKU-by-SKU review (time-consuming, inconsistent)
Cross-impact analysis missing (bundle requirements, substitution)
Customer segment needs ignored (gluten-free, organic, premium)
No optimization (gut-feel decisions vs data-driven)

agentic.workflow: 1. Assortment Optimization Agent analyzes 250 SKU cereal category across multiple dimensions: sales velocity, profitability (margin), customer ratings, strategic value (only gluten-free option?), substitutability. 2. Agent scores each SKU: 'SKU#123 low sales (10 units/month) BUT only gluten-free option + 4.5 star rating + no substitutes = KEEP. SKU#456 low sales (15 units/month) BUT 40% margin (vs 20% category average) = KEEP. SKU#789 low sales (8 units/month) + low margin (15%) + 2.8 star rating + 3 similar substitutes = DISCONTINUE'. 3. Agent identifies 60 SKUs for discontinuation (24% reduction): collectively represent 2% revenue but 8% complexity cost (inventory, logistics, shelf space). 4. Cross-Impact Agent validates: 'SKU#789 discontinuation drives 70% volume to SKU#790 (similar product, higher margin) + saves $50K annual complexity cost'. 5. Agent optimizes to 190 SKUs maintaining 98% revenue, improving category profitability 12% through better mix. 6. 15-25% SKU reduction with 98%+ revenue retention through multi-criteria optimization.
dataSources: SKU sales velocity by location and time period
Strategic attributes (dietary needs, brand portfolio, exclusives)
Substitution patterns (what customers buy when SKU unavailable)
benefits: 15-25% SKU reduction vs 10-15% manual approach
98%+ revenue retention (vs 90-95% volume-only analysis)
Multi-criteria optimization (sales, margin, ratings, strategic value)
Cross-impact analysis prevents unintended consequences
Complexity cost savings ($50K annual per category)
Category profitability improvement 12% through better mix

quickWins: Deploy SKU scoring for top 5 categories with sales, margin, ratings criteria
Implement substitution analysis to validate discontinuation impact
Create quarterly assortment review process vs annual
prerequisites: SKU sales and profitability data (12-24 months history)
Customer ratings and review data integration
Strategic attribute tagging (dietary, exclusive, bundle-required)
Substitution modeling based on purchase patterns
Complexity cost allocation by SKU
Assortment optimization platform or analytics tools

label: Space-to-Sales Allocation
description: Planogram optimization with shelf elasticity modeling achieving 10-20% sales lift through optimal shelf space allocation aligned to demand and profitability.

traditional.workflow: 1. Category manager allocates shelf space based on current sales: 'SKU#A sells 100 units/week, gets 10 shelf facings. SKU#B sells 50 units/week, gets 5 facings'. 2. Equal space-to-sales ratio applied across all SKUs: current sales performance drives space allocation. 3. No consideration of shelf elasticity: 'Would SKU#B sell more if given better visibility and more facings?'. 4. High-margin SKUs treated same as low-margin: both allocated space proportional to sales. 5. Premium eye-level shelf space not optimized: low-margin commodity items at eye level, high-margin specialty at bottom shelf. 6. 10-20% sales opportunity missed due to suboptimal shelf allocation.
constraints: Space allocated proportional to current sales only (circular logic)
Shelf elasticity not modeled (incremental sales from more space)
Margin not considered (low-margin gets same treatment as high-margin)
Eye-level premium space not optimized
Manual planogram design (time-consuming, inconsistent)
10-20% sales lift opportunity missed

agentic.workflow: 1. Space Allocation Agent analyzes shelf elasticity by SKU: 'SKU#B shows 15% sales lift per additional facing (high elasticity), SKU#A shows 3% lift (low elasticity, already saturated)'. 2. Agent models profitability: 'SKU#B generates $8 margin per unit, SKU#A generates $3 - prioritize high-margin SKUs for premium space'. 3. Optimization Agent recommends reallocation: 'Reduce SKU#A from 10 to 8 facings (-6% sales, -$180 margin), increase SKU#B from 5 to 7 facings (+30% sales, +$600 margin) - net category margin +$420/week'. 4. Eye-Level Agent places high-margin items at optimal height: 'Move SKU#B to eye level (50-65 inches height, 40% sales lift vs bottom shelf), move commodity SKU#A to lower shelf (minimal impact)'. 5. Agent designs planogram: 190 SKUs optimized across 48 linear feet of shelf space maximizing category profitability. 6. 10-20% sales lift achieved through shelf elasticity-based optimization vs sales-proportional allocation.
dataSources: SKU sales by shelf position and facing count (elasticity data)
Shelf space constraints (linear feet, height zones)
Visual merchandising rules (brand blocking, vertical alignment)
Customer shopping behavior (heat maps, dwell time)
benefits: 10-20% sales lift through shelf elasticity optimization
Category profitability +$420/week example (high-margin SKUs prioritized)
Eye-level premium space allocated to high-elasticity, high-margin items
Automated planogram design vs manual (hours vs days)
Consistent optimization across all stores (no local variation)
Continuous improvement through elasticity learning

quickWins: Model shelf elasticity for top 50 SKUs in 3 pilot categories
Optimize eye-level space allocation for high-margin items
Deploy automated planogram design for 10 pilot stores
prerequisites: Shelf elasticity data (test different facing counts, measure sales impact)
SKU profitability data (margin, contribution by SKU)
Planogram design software (JDA, Apollo, Shelf Logic)
Store layout and fixture data
Visual merchandising rules and brand guidelines
A/B testing capability for planogram effectiveness

label: New Product Introduction Planning
description: Launch readiness orchestration with space planning and delisting decisions achieving 70-80% new product success rate versus 50-60% through systematic launch preparation.

traditional.workflow: 1. New keto ice cream SKU launching next month, category manager receives notification: 'Find shelf space for new product'. 2. Manager reviews current planogram: 250 SKUs, shelf 100% full, no available space. 3. Hastily selects SKU to discontinue: 'This one has low sales, remove it', no detailed analysis. 4. Launch day: new SKU placed on bottom shelf (only available space), minimal visibility. 5. Post-launch: new SKU underperforms (hard to find, poor placement), discontinued SKU was key item for senior customers (complaints). 6. 50-60% new product success rate due to poor launch preparation and space planning.
constraints: Reactive space planning (find space last minute)
Hasty delisting decisions (no detailed analysis of discontinuation impact)
Suboptimal shelf placement (bottom shelf, low visibility)
50-60% new product success rate
Launch readiness checklist manual (often incomplete)
No cross-functional coordination (merchandising, marketing, supply chain)

Agent validates delisting: 'SKU#123 discontinuation drives 80% volume to SKU#124 (similar product), minimal revenue loss. SKU#456 end-of-season timing optimal'. 4. Placement Agent optimizes shelf position: 'New keto SKU eye-level placement (high visibility), adjacent to keto-friendly products (cross-sell opportunity), end-cap promotion week 1'. 5. Readiness Agent orchestrates launch: coordinates inventory delivery, planogram updates, staff training, promotional signage, supply chain readiness. 6. 70-80% new product success rate through systematic 12-week launch preparation vs 1-2 week reactive approach.

Cross-functional readiness coordination (inventory, training, marketing)
Launch playbook standardization (consistent execution)

label: Assortment Localization (by Store/Cluster)
description: Store clustering with demand-driven local assortments achieving 15-25% sales lift in localized categories versus one-size-fits-all corporate assortment through demographic matching.

traditional.workflow: 1. Corporate merchandising creates single 250-SKU cereal assortment for all 500 stores nationwide. 2. Store in Miami (Hispanic demographic, 85°F average temp) receives same assortment as store in Minneapolis (Nordic demographic, 35°F average). 3. Miami store: gluten-free and organic SKUs don't sell (demographic mismatch), but no Cuban-style cereal options. Minneapolis store: tropical fruit cereal doesn't sell, but lacks hot cereal options. 4. Store managers complain: 'This assortment doesn't fit my customers', request local adjustments. 5. Corporate maintains one-size-fits-all policy (complexity concerns, lack of local demand data). 6. 15-25% sales opportunity missed due to demographic and climate mismatch.
constraints: One-size-fits-all corporate assortment (ignores local demographics)
Demographic mismatch (Hispanic vs Nordic communities same assortment)
Climate mismatch (tropical vs cold weather products)
15-25% sales lift opportunity missed in localized categories
Store manager requests ignored (no systematic localization process)
Complexity concerns prevent localization (manage 500 different assortments)

agentic.workflow: 1. Store Clustering Agent analyzes 500 stores across demographics, climate, sales patterns: creates 12 store clusters (Urban Hispanic, Suburban Family, College Town, Senior Community, etc.). 2. Agent profiles each cluster: 'Cluster 3 (Urban Hispanic, 85 stores): 65% Hispanic population, 80°F average temp, preferences: Latin flavors, organic, gluten-free low demand'. 3. Localization Agent customizes assortment by cluster: 'Cluster 3: remove 15 low-selling gluten-free SKUs, add 12 Latin flavor SKUs (dulce de leche, churro, horchata cereals), add 3 tropical fruit options'. 4. Agent validates localization impact: 'Cluster 3 pilot (10 stores): localized assortment drives +22% category sales, +18% margin, customer satisfaction +15% (better selection fit)'. 5. Agent rolls out to all 85 Cluster 3 stores: corporate manages 12 cluster assortments (vs 500 store-specific) - manageable complexity. 6. 15-25% sales lift in localized categories through demographic-matched assortments vs one-size-fits-all.
dataSources: Store demographics (age, ethnicity, income, household size)
SKU sales by store and category
Customer purchase patterns and preferences by location
Competitor assortments in each trade area
benefits: 15-25% sales lift in localized categories through demographic matching
12 cluster assortments vs 1 corporate or 500 store-specific (manageable)
Customer satisfaction +15% (better selection fit)
Margin improvement +18% (optimize mix for local preferences)
Pilot validation before rollout (reduce risk)
Continuous learning (cluster performance tracking)

quickWins: Cluster 50 pilot stores into 3-5 groups by demographics and sales patterns
Localize 2 test categories (e.g., cereal, beverages) in pilot clusters
Measure sales lift and customer satisfaction in pilot before scaling

SKU performance data by store and category

label: Seasonal Assortment Planning
description: Seasonal flow planning with pre-season positioning and post-season clearance achieving 30-50% markdown reduction through optimized lifecycle inventory management.

traditional.workflow: 1. Halloween seasonal items ordered in July: 10,000 units pumpkin-flavored products based on last year sales. 2. Items arrive late August, placed on shelf, sell through October 31. 3. November 1: 3,500 units remaining (65% sell-through, 35% leftover). 4. Deep markdowns required: 50% off Nov 1-7, then 75% off, some items donated or destroyed. 5. $35,000 markdown loss on unsold seasonal inventory (35% × 10,000 × $10 cost × 50-75% markdown). 6. Next year: repeat same pattern (no systematic seasonal flow planning or markdown optimization).
constraints: Fixed seasonal quantity based on last year (no demand forecasting)
65% sell-through typical (35% leftover requiring markdowns)
Deep markdowns 50-75% to clear seasonal inventory
$35,000 markdown loss per seasonal event (example)
No pre-season demand sensing or mid-season adjustment
Post-season clearance reactive (wait until excess obvious)

agentic.workflow: 1. Seasonal Planning Agent forecasts Halloween demand: '8,500 units projected based on trend analysis (declining pumpkin interest -15% YoY), weather forecast (warm October reduces fall product demand), social media sentiment (keto trend impacts sugary Halloween items)'. 2. Agent plans seasonal flow: 'Initial order 7,000 units (conservative), monitor daily sales, reserve 2,000 units fast-ship option if demand exceeds forecast'. 3. Mid-Season Agent tracks sell-through: 'Week 2 of October: 40% sold (on track for 85% total sell-through), trending better than forecast, release 1,000 additional units from reserve'. 4. Clearance Agent triggers markdown strategy: 'October 28: 90% sold, 800 units remaining, start 30% markdown Oct 29-31 (lighter markdown, still sell remaining units by Halloween)'. 5. Final results: 95% sell-through, 400 units remaining, 30-40% markdown (vs 50-75%), markdown loss $4,000 (vs $35,000). 6. 30-50% markdown reduction through demand-driven seasonal planning vs last-year-based ordering.
dataSources: Social media sentiment and trend analysis
Dietary and health trends (keto, organic impact)
Fast-ship supply options and lead times
benefits: 30-50% markdown reduction ($35K → $4K example, 88% savings)
85-95% sell-through vs 65% (better demand matching)
Mid-season adjustments (add 1,000 units if trending high)
Lighter markdowns 30-40% vs 50-75% (preserve margin)
Demand forecasting vs last-year-based (trend and sentiment analysis)
Reserve inventory strategy (flexibility without over-commitment)
metrics: Planning approach: ML demand forecast + reserve

Implement mid-season sell-through tracking and alerts
Create reserve inventory strategy with fast-ship suppliers

label: Assortment Performance Tracking
description: Continuous assortment KPI monitoring with automated insights achieving 20-30% faster decision-making and 90%+ assortment effectiveness versus quarterly manual reviews.

traditional.workflow: 1. Quarterly business review: category manager exports sales data, manually calculates assortment KPIs in Excel. 2. Metrics calculated: sales by SKU, inventory turns, out-of-stock rate, new product performance. 3. Analysis reveals: 'SKU#789 hasn't sold in 3 months (dead stock), new product SKU#456 outperforming forecast by 200% (missed opportunity)'. 4. Actions identified too late: 3 months of dead stock holding costs ($5K), 3 months of stockouts on hot new product (lost $50K revenue). 5. Quarterly review frequency too slow for fast-moving markets (decisions delayed 90 days). 6. 70-80% assortment effectiveness due to delayed insights and reactive decisions.
constraints: Quarterly review frequency (90-day decision lag)
Manual KPI calculation in Excel (time-consuming, error-prone)
70-80% assortment effectiveness (slow to optimize)
Dead stock identified 3 months late ($5K holding cost waste)
High-performing items stockout while waiting for quarterly review
No automated alerts or exception reporting

agentic.workflow: 1. Performance Tracking Agent monitors assortment KPIs daily: sales velocity, inventory turns, out-of-stock rate, new product performance, customer ratings, profitability. 2. Agent detects exceptions automatically: 'SKU#789 zero sales 14 days (dead stock alert), recommend clearance markdown or discontinuation'. 'SKU#456 selling 3x forecast, stockout risk in 5 days, recommend expedited replenishment'. 3. Agent generates automated insights: 'Category A: 12 SKUs (5% of assortment) driving 60% of sales (power items), 45 SKUs (18%) contributed <1% sales (rationalization candidates)'. 4. Decision Support Agent recommends actions: 'Discontinue 15 slow-movers (free $50K working capital), double inventory on 8 power items (capture $80K incremental revenue)'. 5. Agent tracks action effectiveness: 'Last month recommendations: discontinued 12 SKUs, freed $42K working capital, added 2 SKUs, generated $25K incremental revenue, net benefit $67K'. 6. 20-30% faster decision-making (daily insights vs quarterly review), 90%+ assortment effectiveness through continuous optimization.
